awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SAI: A Study of Mitigation Decisions for America's Coastal Residential Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Strengthening American Infrastructure (SAI) is an NSF Program seeking to stimulate human-centered fundamental and potentially transformative research that strengthens America’s infrastructure. Effective infrastructure provides a strong foundation for socioeconomic vitality and broad quality of life improvement. Strong, reliable, and effective infrastructure spurs private-sector innovation, grows the economy, creates jobs, makes public-sector service provision more efficient, strengthens communities, promotes equal opportunity, protects the natural environment, enhances national security, and fuels American leadership. To achieve these goals requires expertise from across the science and engineering disciplines. SAI focuses on how knowledge of human reasoning and decision making, governance, and social and cultural processes enables the building and maintenance of effective infrastructure that improves lives and society and builds on advances in technology and engineering.

This study examines the perspectives and decisions of homeowners who reside in coastal communities that are subject to extreme weather events, such as hurricanes. Residents have opportunities to strengthen their homes against the risk of hurricanes, and the decisions to make these investments depend in part on their assessments of the risks and possible consequences. To make informed decisions, homeowners need to know not only the risks of extreme weather, but also how different types of homes and building materials are impacted by extreme weather. In order to assess the cognitive basis for these decisions, the researchers aim to assess perspectives and experiences via a diverse, representative survey of homeowners in a coastal region that includes residents who have been directly impacted by hurricanes. This study supports the development of sustainable residential infrastructure in regions that are subject to extreme weather. The study also provides opportunities for the training of graduate students in the methods of scientific data collection and analysis.

By drawing on interdisciplinary methods and data archives, this project develops a new methodological framework that identifies features of homes in the study region, the damage they sustained in a hurricane, and the inferred characteristics of residential households. Equipped with these data, which allow for robust sampling methods, the researchers aim to administer a standardized survey with modules suitable for testing site-specific and event-specific hypotheses regarding homeowner decision processes following a major hurricane. These sampling and survey data enable researchers to efficiently deploy this methodology following major hurricanes across different coastal communities. The responses of survey participants allow the researchers to examine multiple research questions. For instance, do homeowners perceive the risk of catastrophic loss, or have building codes unintentionally fostered a false sense of security? How do experiences of direct losses versus indirect impacts influence risk perceptions and voluntary uptake of enhanced construction standards among homeowners? How do household economic and social dynamics influence the decision to reduce hurricane risks through enhanced construction standards? The answers to these questions can help local stakeholders to craft policies that incentivize homeowners to strengthen residential infrastructure in areas that are subject to natural disasters.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Homes are foundational to flourishing communities. They provide the safety and security necessary for thriving livelihoods, health, education, and other dimensions of well-being. Unfortunately, this vital infrastructure is at significant risk, a risk that is increasing due to the escalating threats of hurricanes in a changing climate. Current regulations and building codes have proven ineffective in stemming mounting coastal losses and keeping families safe, forcing individual homeowners to adopt enhanced construction standards on a voluntary basis. Regrettably, uptake has been limited. It is thus imperative to understand why. This project contributed to such improved understanding by developing a new research methodology to study homeowner actions in a post-hurricane landscape where damage necessitates reconstruction decisions. This research methodology is founded on a novel modular survey instrument robust enough to document diverse damage experiences and recovery journeys. This survey can be deployed using a new sampling methodology that efficiently targets households most likely to be engaged in recovery actions. The collected responses then feed into a series of indices that provide a detailed accounting of homeowners' protective actions over time and a holistic measure of their damage experiences. The resulting research methodology was then deployed in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana to demonstrate its efficacy and generate data to study 373 homeowners still recovering from 2020's Hurricane Laura.

The initial findings suggest that respondents had high rates of damage exposure, both to their own homes and through the experiences of family, friends, and neighbors. 95% of respondents' homes were damaged in Hurricane Laura, with damage primarily concentrated in roofs and windows. Nearly all respondents had friends and family whose homes sustained severe damage, in addition to the daily reminder of damaged homes in their neighborhood and along their daily commute. The typical homeowner had taken action to protect their home prior to the hurricane. Informed by their experiences, they "built back better" after the hurricane, with repair actions that increased their home's protection, largely by investing in new roofs and impact-rated windows or storm shutters. While much of these investments center on replacing damaged components with superior products, the majority of those who did not have damage but voluntarily retrofitted after the storm invested in hurricane clips or straps, an indicator that the widespread destruction across this community inspired some to "build better before" the next storm. Unfortunately, the totality of those actions to date still leave the typical household with insufficient protections to resist the next major hurricane. While the average homeowner intends to invest in more protections in the future, this would still be insufficient to achieve the comprehensive protections needed for a storm like Hurricane Laura. Notably, homeowners who experienced no damage in Hurricane Laura had made more investments to protect their home prior to the storm, and they intend to invest even more than their peers in protection in the future, likely due to the favorable return on their past investments. In total, these promising yet inadequate observed actions suggest there are opportunities for incentive programs and consumer education to bolster homeowners' current efforts to achieve the whole-house protections necessary to combat a changing climate.

The rich dataset introduced by this paper, inclusive of robust measures of homeowner protective actions and damage exposure, will enable the discovery of these incentives and outreach messages. Ongoing investigations using the collected data will reveal how causal factors motivating homeowner adaptation decisions shaped these households' diverse recovery experiences and will suggest how to better incentivize them to make protective investments that keep pace with the escalating threats facing their community. Moreover, the developed research methodology's dissemination through NSF's National Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) will support future replication studies along the Gulf and Atlantic coasts to similarly mobilize hurricane-resilient construction practices across some of America's most climate-vulnerable communities.
